review_title: Good to build portifolio, classes not good
job_title: MSC Graduate Student in Bournemouth, England
pros: As an MSc student at Bournemouth University, I have found it to be an excellent opportunity to build my portfolio and gain practical experience in my field. The university provides ample opportunities for students to participate in various projects, internships, and other extracurricular activities. This has helped me enhance my skills and knowledge, which will undoubtedly benefit me in my future career.
cons: However, the classes at Bournemouth University are not always of the highest quality. Some courses lack structure, and the lecturers' teaching styles can be disorganized and confusing at times. Additionally, there is a lack of consistency in the quality of teaching across different modules, which can be frustrating for students. The university could benefit from investing more in its teaching staff to ensure that students receive the highest quality education possible. Overall, while the university has its strengths, there is certainly room for improvement in certain areas

review_title: Like all places: it has its ups and downs, light and shade, rough and ..... less rough.
pros: The colleagues were on the whole great, hard-working and very collegiate. Teaching was of a high standard in the faculty, and most of the students worked really hard. There has been some significant campus estate investment, though that is mainly to "wow" the public and the students. Staff facilities......
cons: ......well, staff facilities (office space etc) are much lower on the order of investment priorities - and it is really beginning to show in some areas. There is also an issue with workload planning, which is not done properly in some departments, resulting in a lot of overworked staff. Officially there is a clear directive on academic teaching / contact hours..... but a lot of contact hours fall below the radar - particulalry in areas of assessment and tutorial support. Successful allocation of workloads sadly depends on whether you happen to have a good line manager, or whether you have a line manager who just doesn't understand the sizeable element of academic workload that lies beneath the surface of their spreadsheets. For instance in heavily increased administrative work processes, that used to be carried out by admin colleagues, but following "efficiency drives" (cutting back on admin staff) this work has been delegated to software processes, that need to be managed by academic staff in addition to their academic duties. There has also been a dizzying increase in bureaucracy in the overall HE sector, and this is very much apparent within this HE institution.

review_title: Amazing place to work - the best!
pros: I feel valued and looked after - both part of the team and valued for my individual contribution.  I feel well supported both professionally and personally - I have previously completed a fully funded MA and now I am in the second year of a fully funded PhD.  I have been supported with funding for professional development and have attended professional training courses both within the university and outside...
cons: Not many that I am aware of - there are some support departments that misuse H&S, legal, discrimination and environmental considerations to derail progress.  I see these areas as important considerations around which risk to the organisation should be assessed - however, once appropriate discussion and suitable control measures are applied these considerations should not prevent progress.

pros:
- Nice area and the beach, relatively close to London.
- Very good in certain areas, computer graphics, tourism, tribology.
- Some great supervisors and rese
- Great community of fellow PhD students.
cons:
- Lack of experience in certain areas. So it is suggested to research the Bournemouth University staff who is specialising in the area of applicant's interest.
- If you are unlucky, you may have big problems with supervisors, effectively ruining the PhD experience.
- Organisation of PhD is a bit chaotic. Lot of unnecessary workshops.
- Campuses are small and not vibrant. Particularly Lansdowne Campus in downtown Bournemouth.
- One of the most expensive parts of the UK to live in, but still nowhere as expensive as London.

job_title: Principal Network Engineer in Bournemouth, England
pros:
Great tech to get your hands on & great to learn and grow: if you want to learn something, you can generally get some hands on time & experience. There are some great technicians on the 'coal face'. It's not a bad place to work and a lot of people stay for years & years. Colleagues are a good lot, on the whole.
Flexible around families, good holidays.
cons: Weak management (think this can change depending on what area you are working within the university). It can be a little like the wild west. There is a bit of a blame culture, but no real mechanisms to follow up. Lots of slippy shoulders.

pros:
Great part-time job to manage along side your studies. 
Only requires an hour of prep every week and then another hour of actual facilitation time. 
Easy way to earn some extra income especially if you enjoy your course and are doing well in it too. 
Lots of support for the role from the department - offers advice on how to structure your sessions and offers some content ideas too.
cons: Can't guarantee that students will attend your sessions.

pros: Good team at Bournemouth Uni and a very enjoyable place to work. No complaints really. Benefits such as holiday very good.
cons: Salaries will never be as high as some private sector positions but that is to be expected. Large organisations can also have downsides compared to smaller or medium ones
